summary: This study established and characterized DB-1, a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line, as an in vitro tool to investigate the link between leptin and innate immunity. The DB-1 cells, which spontaneously immortalized at approximately passage 20, are diploid, grow linearly for 4–5 days, and are MAC-2 and F4/80 positive with phagocytic activity similar to primary macrophages. Notably, DB-1 cells were responsive to interferon-γ stimulation by increasing Nos2 transcript levels but were unresponsive to leptin or adipocyte conditioned media chemotaxis, making them a dependable tool for studying leptin's role in obesity-associated inflammation and immune system dysregulation.
impact: Scientifically, this publication provides a significant methodological advancement by developing and thoroughly characterizing the DB-1 cell line, offering a novel in vitro model for dissecting the complex interplay between leptin signaling and innate immune responses. While primarily focused on obesity-associated inflammation terrestrially, understanding fundamental mechanisms of immune system dysregulation can indirectly inform research relevant to astronaut health, as altered immunity is a concern in spaceflight. This robust tool facilitates future research into specific leptin-mediated pathways, potentially aiding in drug discovery and broader investigations into metabolic-immune crosstalk.
original_title: Establishment and characterization of DB-1: a leptin receptor-deficient murine macrophage cell line

title: Validation of Methods to Assess the Immunoglobulin Gene Repertoire in Tissues Obtained from Mice on the International Space Station
abstract: Spaceflight is known to affect immune cell populations. In particular, splenic B cell numbers decrease during spaceflight and in ground-based physiological models. Although antibody isotype changes have been assessed during and after space flight, an extensive characterization of the impact of spaceflight on antibody composition has not been conducted in mice. Next Generation Sequencing and bioinformatic tools are now available to assess antibody repertoires. We can now identify immunoglobulin gene- segment usage, junctional regions, and modifications that contribute to specificity and diversity. Due to limitations on the International Space Station, alternate sample collection and storage methods must be employed. Our group compared Illumina MiSeq sequencing data from multiple sample preparation methods in normal C57Bl/6J mice to validate that sample preparation and storage would not bias the outcome of antibody repertoire characterization. In this report, we also compared sequencing techniques and a bioinformatic workflow on the data output when we assessed the IgH and Igκ variable gene usage. This included assessments of our bioinformatic workflow on Illumina HiSeq and MiSeq datasets and is specifically designed to reduce bias, capture the most information from Ig sequences, and produce a data set that provides other data mining options. We validated our workflow by comparing our normal mouse MiSeq data to existing murine antibody repertoire studies validating it for future antibody repertoire studies.

Application of MiSeq Workflow to RR1 HiSeq Data

summary: This study validated sample preparation, storage methods, sequencing techniques (Illumina MiSeq and HiSeq), and a bioinformatic workflow for characterizing immunoglobulin gene repertoires (IgH and Igκ variable gene usage) in mouse tissues. The primary objective was to ensure unbiased data collection for future International Space Station (ISS) studies, where sample handling is constrained. The research confirmed that their developed workflow, including size selection and reference/IgH locus mapping, provides comprehensive data comparable to existing murine antibody repertoire studies, thus enabling extensive characterization of spaceflight's impact on antibody composition.
impact: Scientifically, this publication offers a crucial methodological advancement for space immunology, establishing a robust next-generation sequencing and bioinformatic workflow for immunoglobulin repertoire analysis under spaceflight conditions. Practically, this work is vital for NASA's Space Biology program, facilitating accurate assessment of spaceflight effects on the murine immune system and thereby informing astronaut health strategies and countermeasure development. The validated techniques also hold broader implications for high-fidelity antibody repertoire studies in other challenging biological contexts beyond space exploration.

title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Antibody specificity and diversity are generated through the enzymatic splicing of genomic gene segments within each B cell. Antibodies are heterodimers of heavy- and light-chains encoded on separate loci. We studied the antibody repertoire from pooled, splenic tissue of unimmunized, adult female C57BL/6J mice, using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) without amplification of antibody transcripts. We recovered over 90,000 heavy-chain and over 135,000 light-chain immunoglobulin sequences. Individual V-, D-, and J-gene segment usage was uniform among the three mouse pools, particularly in highly abundant gene segments, with low frequency V-gene segments not being detected in all pools. Despite the similar usage of individual gene segments, the repertoire of individual B-cell CDR3 amino acid sequences in each mouse pool was highly varied, affirming the combinatorial diversity in the B-cell pool that has been previously demonstrated. There also was some skewing in the V-gene segments that were detected depending on chromosomal location. This study presents a unique, non-primer biased glimpse of the conventionally housed, unimmunized antibody repertoire of the C57BL6/J mouse.
summary: This study aimed to characterize the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing of splenic tissue from unimmunized C57BL/6J mice. Researchers recovered over 90,000 heavy-chain and over 135,000 light-chain immunoglobulin sequences, finding uniform individual V-, D-, and J-gene segment usage but highly varied B-cell CDR3 amino acid sequences. This work provides a unique, non-primer biased view of the unimmunized antibody repertoire, affirming combinatorial diversity.
impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances the understanding of baseline immune system genetics by providing a non-primer biased, high-throughput sequencing method for characterizing naive antibody repertoires. While not directly applied to space missions in this paper, understanding the fundamental, naive immune state is crucial for identifying and developing countermeasures against immune dysregulation, a known challenge for astronaut health during spaceflight. Broader implications include establishing a robust baseline for immune research, improving vaccine design, and facilitating the study of immune changes in response to various stressors, both terrestrial and extraterrestrial.
original_title: Characterization of the naive murine antibody repertoire using unamplified high-throughput sequencing

title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice
abstract: Spaceflight has been shown to suppress the adaptive immune response, altering the distribution and function of lymphocyte populations. B lymphocytes express highly specific and highly diversified receptors, known as immunoglobulins (Ig), that directly bind and neutralize pathogens. Ig diversity is achieved through the enzymatic splicing of gene segments within the genomic DNA of each B cell in a host. The collection of Ig specificities within a host, or Ig repertoire, has been increasingly characterized in both basic research and clinical settings using high-throughput sequencing technology (HTS). We utilized HTS to test the hypothesis that spaceflight affects the B-cell repertoire. To test this hypothesis, we characterized the impact of spaceflight on the unimmunized Ig repertoire of C57BL/6 mice that were flown aboard the International Space Station (ISS) during the Rodent Research One validation flight in comparison to ground controls. Individual gene segment usage was similar between ground control and flight animals, however, gene segment combinations and the junctions in which gene segments combine was varied among animals within and between treatment groups. We also found that spontaneous somatic mutations in the IgH and Igκ gene loci were not increased. These data suggest that space flight did not affect the B cell repertoire of mice flown and housed on the ISS over a short period of time.
summary: This study utilized high-throughput sequencing to test the hypothesis that spaceflight affects the unimmunized B-cell immunoglobulin (Ig) repertoire of C57BL/6 mice aboard the ISS. It found that individual gene segment usage was similar between ground control and flight animals, and spontaneous somatic mutations in IgH and Igκ gene loci were not increased. The data suggest that spaceflight over a short period did not significantly affect the B-cell repertoire of mice housed on the ISS.
impact: This research provides crucial insights into astronaut immune health by specifically assessing the B-cell repertoire, challenging the general assumption of immune suppression for this component over short durations in space. Methodologically, it advances space biology by applying high-throughput sequencing for detailed Ig repertoire analysis. These findings are vital for developing targeted countermeasures and informing mission planning, particularly for extended human spaceflight, to ensure astronaut well-being.
original_title: Effects of spaceflight on the immunoglobulin repertoire of unimmunized C57BL/6 mice

title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing
abstract: Sequencing antibody repertoires has steadily become cheaper and easier. Sequencing methods usually rely on some form of amplification, often a massively multiplexed PCR prior to sequencing. To eliminate potential biases and create a data set that could be used for other studies, our lab compared unamplified sequencing results from the splenic heavy-chain repertoire in the mouse to those processed through two commercial applications. We also compared the use of mRNA vs total RNA, reverse transcriptase, and primer usage for cDNA synthesis and submission. The use of mRNA for cDNA synthesis resulted in higher read counts but reverse transcriptase and primer usage had no statistical effects on read count. Although most of the amplified data sets contained more antibody reads than the unamplified data set, we detected more unique V-gene segments in the unamplified data set. Although unique CDR3 detection was much lower in the unamplified data set, RNASeq detected 98% of the high frequency CDR3s. We have shown that unamplified profiling of the antibody repertoire is possible, detects more V-gene segments, and detects high frequency clones in the repertoire.
summary: This study compared unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine splenic heavy-chain antibody repertoire sequencing to minimize biases, also investigating mRNA vs. total RNA, reverse transcriptase, and primer usage. Key findings revealed that while amplified data sets had more antibody reads, the unamplified method detected more unique V-gene segments, and RNASeq identified 98% of high-frequency CDR3s. The research demonstrates that unamplified antibody repertoire profiling is feasible, offers enhanced V-gene segment detection, and accurately identifies high-frequency clones.
impact: This study significantly advances immunosequencing methodology by demonstrating that unamplified profiling of antibody repertoires is possible and provides more unique V-gene segments, potentially reducing amplification biases. For space biology, this refined technique could lead to more accurate assessment of astronaut immune system changes during space missions, aiding in health monitoring and the development of targeted countermeasures. Broader implications include improved understanding of immune responses in diverse contexts, impacting vaccine development and immunological research on Earth.
original_title: A comparison of unamplified and massively multiplexed PCR amplification for murine antibody repertoire sequencing.

title: Preclinical development of TAK-754, a high-performance AAV8-based vector expressing coagulation factor VIII
abstract: This report concerns the preclinical development of TAK-754, an AAV8-based human factor VIII (FVIII) vector designed to deliver a codon-optimized and CpG-depleted B domain-deleted F8 transgene under the control of a liver-specific promoter for gene therapy in patients with hemophilia A. A dose-dependent increase in plasma FVIII activity was detected in FVIII knockout mice at a dose of 1.0 × 10^12 TAK-754 capsid particles (CP)/kg or higher. This increase was shown to be in accordance with a dose-dependent decrease in blood loss in a hemostatic efficacy assay. TAK-754 (3.1 × 10^12 CP/kg) mediated long-term and stable FVIII expression in immunologically tolerant transgenic human FVIII mice. Toxicology and biodistribution assessments with a single administration of TAK-754 ranging between 1.9 × 10^12 and 5.0 × 10^13 CP/kg were conducted in male C57BL/6J mice. The highest TAK-754 dose occurred without TAK-754-related adverse clinical signs. Biodistribution profiling showed predominant detection in the liver with a low occurrence of vector DNA in other tissues. Integration site analysis revealed minimal vector integration, with no observations of clonal outgrowth or preferred integrations in genes previously implicated in hepatocellular carcinoma formation within the observation period. These preclinical studies demonstrate a good safety and efficacy profile for TAK-754.
summary: This report details the preclinical development of TAK-754, an AAV8-based gene therapy vector for hemophilia A, demonstrating its safety and efficacy. Key findings include a dose-dependent increase in plasma FVIII activity at 1.0 × 10^12 TAK-754 CP/kg or higher in FVIII knockout mice, leading to reduced blood loss, and long-term, stable FVIII expression in transgenic mice at 3.1 × 10^12 CP/kg. Toxicology studies showed no adverse clinical signs up to 5.0 × 10^13 CP/kg, predominant liver biodistribution, and minimal vector integration without tumorigenic risk, establishing a favorable profile for future clinical use.
impact: Scientifically, this study significantly advances gene therapy for hemophilia A by providing robust preclinical data on the safety and efficacy of a high-performance AAV8 vector, including detailed biodistribution and integration analysis at high doses. While focused on a terrestrial medical application, the rigorous methodology for assessing gene therapy vector safety and long-term expression offers valuable insights for future research in gene editing and therapeutic development, which could eventually have implications for countermeasure development or health maintenance in extreme environments if similar genetic approaches are explored. Its successful preclinical profile paves the way for clinical trials, promising a potential new treatment for hemophilia A patients.

title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity
abstract: Ab repertoire diversity plays a critical role in the host’s ability to fight pathogens. CDR3 is partially responsible for Ab–Ag binding and is a significant source of diversity in the repertoire. CDR3 diversity is generated during VDJ rearrangement because of gene segment selection, gene segment trimming and splicing, and the addition of nucleotides. We analyzed the Ab repertoire diversity across multiple experiments examining the effects of spaceflight on the Ab repertoire after vaccination. Five datasets from four experiments were analyzed using rank-abundance curves and Shannon indices as measures of diversity. We discovered a trend toward lower diversity as a result of spaceflight but did not find the same decrease in our physiological model of microgravity in either the spleen or bone marrow. However, the bone marrow repertoire showed a reduction in diversity after vaccination. We also detected differences in Shannon indices between experiments and tissues. We did not detect a pattern of CDR3 usage across the experiments. Overall, we were able to find differences in the Ab repertoire diversity across experimental groups and tissues.
summary: This study analyzed antibody (Ab) repertoire diversity, focusing on CDR3 diversity, across five datasets from four experiments to investigate the effects of spaceflight and vaccination. A trend toward lower Ab repertoire diversity was discovered as a result of spaceflight, though this decrease was not found in physiological microgravity models in either the spleen or bone marrow. However, the bone marrow repertoire did show a reduction in diversity after vaccination, and differences in Shannon indices were detected between experiments and tissues, highlighting the impact of spaceflight on adaptive immunity.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how the immune system, specifically antibody repertoire diversity crucial for pathogen defense, is affected by spaceflight and vaccination. The findings are vital for assessing astronaut health risks during long-duration space missions, informing vaccination strategies, and potentially guiding the development of immunological countermeasures. By contrasting actual spaceflight data with ground-based microgravity models, it provides valuable insights into adaptive immune responses under space-relevant stressors.
original_title: An Analysis of the Effects of Spaceflight and Vaccination on Antibody Repertoire Diversity

title: Effects of spaceflight aboard the International Space Station on mouse estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression
abstract: Ovarian steroids dramatically impact normal homeostatic and metabolic processes of most tissues within the body, including muscle, bone, neural, immune, cardiovascular, and reproductive systems. Determining the effects of spaceflight on the ovary and estrous cycle is, therefore, critical to our understanding of all spaceflight experiments using female mice. Adult female mice (n = 10) were exposed to and sacrificed on-orbit after 37 days of spaceflight in microgravity. Contemporary control (preflight baseline, vivarium, and habitat; n = 10/group) groups were maintained at the Kennedy Space Center, prior to sacrifice and similar tissue collection at the NASA Ames Research Center. Ovarian tissues were collected and processed for RNA and steroid analyses at initial carcass thaw. Vaginal wall tissue collected from twice frozen/thawed carcasses was fixed for estrous cycle stage determinations. The proportion of animals in each phase of the estrous cycle (i.e., proestrus, estrus, metestrus, and diestrus) did not appreciably differ between baseline, vivarium, and flight mice, while habitat control mice exhibited greater numbers in diestrus. Ovarian tissue steroid concentrations indicated no differences in estradiol across groups, while progesterone levels were lower (p < 0.05) in habitat and flight compared to baseline females. Genes involved in ovarian steroidogenic function were not differentially expressed across groups. As ovarian estrogen can dramatically impact multiple non-reproductive tissues, these data support vaginal wall estrous cycle classification of all female mice flown in space. Additionally, since females exposed to long-term spaceflight were observed at different estrous cycle stages, this indicates females are likely undergoing ovarian cyclicity and may yet be fertile.
summary: This study investigated the effects of 37 days of spaceflight on the estrous cycle and ovarian gene expression in adult female mice (n=10). While estrous cycle stage proportions did not appreciably differ between baseline, vivarium, and flight mice, habitat control mice exhibited greater numbers in diestrus. Ovarian estradiol levels were unchanged, but progesterone was significantly lower (p < 0.05) in habitat and flight groups compared to baseline, with no differential expression in steroidogenic genes. These findings support vaginal wall estrous cycle classification and suggest that female mice likely maintain ovarian cyclicity and potential fertility during long-term spaceflight.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of reproductive physiology in the microgravity environment, a critical area for long-duration space missions. By demonstrating that female mice likely maintain ovarian cyclicity and fertility, it provides crucial insights for assessing astronaut health risks and developing appropriate countermeasures for reproductive well-being during space travel. Published in NPJ Microgravity, these findings are essential for informing future space biology experiments and supporting the planning of missions involving female crewmembers.

title: Effect of spaceflight on Pseudomonas aeruginosa final cell density is modulated by nutrient and oxygen availability
abstract:
Background
Abundant populations of bacteria have been observed on Mir and the International Space Station. While some experiments have shown that bacteria cultured during spaceflight exhibit a range of potentially troublesome characteristics, including increases in growth, antibiotic resistance and virulence, other studies have shown minimal differences when cells were cultured during spaceflight or on Earth. Although the final cell density of bacteria grown during spaceflight has been reported for several species, we are not yet able to predict how different microorganisms will respond to the microgravity environment. In order to build our understanding of how spaceflight affects bacterial final cell densities, additional studies are needed to determine whether the observed differences are due to varied methods, experimental conditions, or organism specific responses.
Results
Here, we have explored how phosphate concentration, carbon source, oxygen availability, and motility affect the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in modified artificial urine media during spaceflight. We observed that P. aeruginosa grown during spaceflight exhibited increased final cell density relative to normal gravity controls when low concentrations of phosphate in the media were combined with decreased oxygen availability. In contrast, when the availability of either phosphate or oxygen was increased, no difference in final cell density was observed between spaceflight and normal gravity. Because motility has been suggested to affect how microbes respond to microgravity, we compared the growth of wild-type P. aeruginosa to a ΔmotABCD mutant deficient in swimming motility. However, the final cell densities observed with the motility mutant were consistent with those observed with wild type for all conditions tested.
Conclusions
These results indicate that differences in bacterial final cell densities observed between spaceflight and normal gravity are due to an interplay between microgravity conditions and the availability of substrates essential for growth. Further, our results suggest that microbes grown under nutrient-limiting conditions are likely to reach higher cell densities under microgravity conditions than they would on Earth. Considering that the majority of bacteria inhabiting spacecrafts and space stations are likely to live under nutrient limitations, our findings highlight the need to explore the impact microgravity and other aspects of the spaceflight environment have on microbial growth and physiology.

summary: This study investigated how spaceflight affects the final cell density of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa*, considering factors like phosphate concentration, oxygen availability, and motility. Key findings revealed that *P. aeruginosa* grown during spaceflight exhibited increased final cell density compared to normal gravity controls when low phosphate concentrations were combined with decreased oxygen availability. Conversely, increasing the availability of either phosphate or oxygen eliminated this difference, and swimming motility did not play a role, highlighting that differences in bacterial final cell densities under spaceflight are due to an interplay between microgravity and essential substrate availability, suggesting nutrient-limited microbes may reach higher densities in microgravity.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of microbial physiology in space, demonstrating how microgravity interacts with specific environmental factors like nutrient and oxygen availability to influence bacterial growth, particularly showing increased density under nutrient-limiting conditions. Practically, these findings are crucial for astronaut health and spacecraft system integrity, as they suggest an increased risk of bacterial proliferation and biofilm formation in the nutrient-limited, low-oxygen environments often found in spacecraft. This work underscores the critical need for further investigation into microbial responses to spaceflight to develop effective countermeasures and ensure mission success and crew safety.

title: Spaceflight Promotes Biofilm Formation by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
abstract: Understanding the effects of spaceflight on microbial communities is crucial for the success of long-term, manned space missions. Surface-associated bacterial communities, known as biofilms, were abundant on the Mir space station and continue to be a challenge on the International Space Station. The health and safety hazards linked to the development of biofilms are of particular concern due to the suppression of immune function observed during spaceflight. While planktonic cultures of microbes have indicated that spaceflight can lead to increases in growth and virulence, the effects of spaceflight on biofilm development and physiology remain unclear. To address this issue, Pseudomonas aeruginosa was cultured during two Space Shuttle Atlantis missions: STS-132 and STS-135, and the biofilms formed during spaceflight were characterized. Spaceflight was observed to increase the number of viable cells, biofilm biomass, and thickness relative to normal gravity controls. Moreover, the biofilms formed during spaceflight exhibited a column-and-canopy structure that has not been observed on Earth. The increase in the amount of biofilms and the formation of the novel architecture during spaceflight were observed to be independent of carbon source and phosphate concentrations in the media. However, flagella-driven motility was shown to be essential for the formation of this biofilm architecture during spaceflight. These findings represent the first evidence that spaceflight affects community-level behaviors of bacteria and highlight the importance of understanding how both harmful and beneficial human-microbe interactions may be altered during spaceflight.
summary: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on the biofilm formation and physiology of *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* during two Space Shuttle Atlantis missions (STS-132 and STS-135). Spaceflight was found to increase viable cell numbers, biofilm biomass, and thickness compared to normal gravity controls. Additionally, a novel column-and-canopy biofilm architecture, dependent on flagella-driven motility, was observed exclusively in space.
impact: This research provides critical scientific insight into how spaceflight uniquely alters microbial community-level behaviors, specifically promoting biofilm growth and novel structural development. These findings are crucial for ensuring astronaut health and safety on long-term manned space missions, as biofilms pose significant challenges on the ISS, especially given observed immune suppression in space. The study highlights the necessity for further research into altered human-microbe interactions and the development of effective countermeasures for biofilm control in space environments.

title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNA-seq data
abstract: With the development of transcriptomic technologies, we are able to quantify precise changes in gene expression profiles from astronauts and other organisms exposed to spaceflight. Members of NASA GeneLab and GeneLab-associated analysis working groups (AWGs) have developed a consensus pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments. The pipeline includes quality control, read trimming, mapping, and gene quantification steps, culminating in the detection of differentially expressed genes. This data analysis pipeline and the results of its execution using data submitted to GeneLab are now all publicly available through the GeneLab database. We present here the full details and rationale for the construction of this pipeline in order to promote transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of pipeline data; to provide a template for data processing of future spaceflight-relevant datasets; and to encourage cross-analysis of data from other databases with the data available in GeneLab.
summary: This NASA GeneLab publication presents a consensus pipeline for standardized processing of short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments. Developed by NASA GeneLab and its working groups, the pipeline encompasses quality control, read trimming, mapping, and gene quantification to detect differentially expressed genes. This publicly available data analysis pipeline aims to enhance transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of spaceflight data, providing a template for future datasets and fostering cross-analysis within the GeneLab database.
impact: This publication significantly advances space biology by providing a standardized, robust methodology for transcriptomic data analysis, thereby improving the reproducibility and comparability of RNA-seq data from spaceflight experiments. The pipeline offers critical practical applications for understanding gene expression changes in astronauts and organisms exposed to space, informing astronaut health, countermeasure development, and future mission planning. Its public availability and detailed rationale promote broader scientific collaboration and accelerate discovery in both space and terrestrial biological research.
original_title: GeneLab: Omics database for spaceflight experiments

title: NASA GeneLab: interfaces for the exploration of space omics data
abstract: The mission of NASA’s GeneLab database (https://genelab.nasa.gov/) is to collect, curate, and provide access to the genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic and metabolomic (so-called ‘omics’) data from biospecimens flown in space or exposed to simulated space stressors, maximizing their utilization. This large collection of data enables the exploration of molecular network responses to space environments using a systems biology approach. We review here the various components of the GeneLab platform, including the new data repository web interface, and the GeneLab Online Data Entry (GEODE) web portal, which will support the expansion of the database in the future to include companion non-omics assay data. We discuss our design for GEODE, particularly how it promotes investigators providing more accurate metadata, reducing the curation effort required of GeneLab staff. We also introduce here a new GeneLab Application Programming Interface (API) specifically designed to support tools for the visualization of processed omics data. We review the outreach efforts by GeneLab to utilize the spaceflight data in the repository to generate novel discoveries and develop new hypotheses, including spearheading data analysis working groups, and a high school student training program. All these efforts are aimed ultimately at supporting precision risk management for human space exploration.
summary: This publication details NASA’s GeneLab database, an essential platform designed to collect, curate, and provide access to genomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic (omics) data from biospecimens exposed to space environments or simulated stressors. The paper reviews GeneLab's new data repository web interface, the GeneLab Online Data Entry (GEODE) portal for improved metadata quality, and a new Application Programming Interface (API) to support data visualization tools. These advancements aim to facilitate the exploration of molecular network responses to space using a systems biology approach, ultimately supporting precision risk management for human space exploration.
impact: This work significantly advances space biology by establishing a centralized and comprehensive resource for multi-omics data, fostering a systems biology approach to understanding spaceflight impacts on biological systems. The development of user-friendly interfaces (GEODE, API) enhances data accessibility, quality, and analytical capabilities, accelerating scientific discovery and the development of countermeasures for astronaut health. Published in Nucleic Acids Research, a leading journal for bioinformatics resources, this platform is critical for enabling precision risk management in future human space missions and serves as a model for large-scale biological data management.

title: Comprehensive Multi-Omics Analysis Reveals Mitochondrial Stress as a Central Biological Hub for Spaceflight Impact
abstract: Spaceflight is known to impose changes on human physiology with unknown molecular etiologies. To reveal these causes, we used a multi-omics, systems biology analytical approach using biomedical profiles from fifty-nine astronauts and data from NASA’s GeneLab derived from hundreds of samples flown in space, to determine transcriptomic, proteomic, metabolomic, and epigenetic responses to spaceflight. Overall pathway analyses on the multi-omic datasets showed significant enrichment for mitochondrial processes, as well as innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, circadian rhythm, and olfactory functions. Importantly, NASA’s Twin Study provided a platform to confirm several of our principal findings. Evidence of altered mitochondrial function and DNA damage was also found in the urine and blood metabolic data compiled from the astronaut cohort and NASA Twin Study data, indicating mitochondrial stress as a consistent phenotype of spaceflight.
summary: To identify molecular etiologies of physiological changes during spaceflight, researchers conducted a comprehensive multi-omics analysis using biomedical profiles from fifty-nine astronauts and hundreds of GeneLab samples. This analysis revealed significant enrichment for mitochondrial processes, innate immunity, chronic inflammation, cell cycle, circadian rhythm, and olfactory functions. The study concluded that mitochondrial stress, including altered function and DNA damage, is a consistent phenotype of spaceflight, confirmed by NASA's Twin Study.
impact: Published in Cell, this study makes a significant scientific contribution by establishing mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact through a robust multi-omics systems biology approach and validation with NASA's Twin Study. Practically, these findings provide crucial molecular insights for understanding astronaut health risks during long-duration space missions, potentially informing the development of targeted countermeasures. Broader implications extend to future research on stress-induced mitochondrial dysfunction and inflammation, with potential terrestrial applications for related health conditions.

original_title: Comprehensive multi-omics analysis reveals mitochondrial stress as a central biological hub for spaceflight impact

title: A New Era for Space Life Science: International Standards for Space Omics Processing
abstract: Space agencies have announced plans for human missions to the Moon to prepare for Mars. However, the space environment presents stressors that include radiation, microgravity, and isolation. Understanding how these factors affect biology is crucial for safe and effective crewed space exploration. There is a need to develop countermeasures, to adapt plants and microbes for nutrient sources and bioregenerative life support, and to limit pathogen infection. Scientists across the world are conducting space omics experiments on model organisms and, more recently, on humans. Optimal extraction of actionable scientific discoveries from these precious datasets will only occur at the collective level with improved standardization. To address this shortcoming, we established ISSOP (International Standards for Space Omics Processing), an international consortium of scientists who aim to enhance standard guidelines between space biologists at a global level. Here we introduce our consortium and share past lessons learned and future challenges related to spaceflight omics.
headings: Past Lessons Learned from Space Omics with Model Organisms
Current Need for a Global Consortium: ISSOP
summary: To address the challenge of extracting actionable scientific discoveries from diverse space omics datasets, an international consortium named ISSOP (International Standards for Space Omics Processing) was established. The primary objective is to enhance standard guidelines among global space biologists, facilitating optimal data integration and analysis. This standardization is deemed crucial for understanding how space stressors affect biology, developing countermeasures for human missions to the Moon and Mars, adapting plants and microbes for life support, and limiting pathogen infection.
impact: This publication significantly advances scientific methodology by proposing and establishing a global consortium for standardizing space omics data processing, which is critical for maximizing insights from valuable spaceflight experiments. Practically, it will enable more effective development of countermeasures, improve astronaut health, and facilitate the design of bioregenerative life support systems for future human space exploration missions to the Moon and Mars. Published in Patterns (N Y) by a large international team, the initiative sets a precedent for enhanced collaboration and data utility, potentially influencing standardization efforts across broader scientific domains beyond space biology.

title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases
abstract: There has long been an interest in understanding how the hazards from spaceflight may trigger or exacerbate human diseases. With the goal of advancing our knowledge on physiological changes during space travel, NASA GeneLab provides an open-source repository of multi-omics data from real and simulated spaceflight studies. Alone, this data enables identification of biological changes during spaceflight, but cannot infer how that may impact an astronaut at the phenotypic level. To bridge this gap, Scalable Precision Medicine Oriented Knowledge Engine (SPOKE), a heterogeneous knowledge graph connecting biological and clinical data from over 30 databases, was used in combination with GeneLab transcriptomic data from six studies. This integration identified critical symptoms and physiological changes incurred during spaceflight.
summary: This study aimed to identify critical symptoms and physiological changes in spaceflown mice to understand how spaceflight impacts health at a phenotypic level. By integrating transcriptomic data from six NASA GeneLab studies with SPOKE, a heterogeneous knowledge graph connecting over 30 biological and clinical databases, researchers successfully uncovered signs and symptoms associated with terrestrial diseases in spaceflight. This approach bridges the gap between molecular changes and their phenotypic manifestation, advancing knowledge on space-induced physiological alterations.
impact: This study significantly advances space biology by providing a novel methodology for linking transcriptomic data to phenotypic outcomes using a sophisticated knowledge graph, thereby bridging a critical gap in understanding astronaut health. Practically, the identified signs and symptoms associated with terrestrial diseases in spaceflown mice offer crucial insights for monitoring astronaut health, developing countermeasures, and ensuring mission safety. The methodology, integrating data from over 30 databases, also has broader implications for terrestrial disease research and personalized medicine, showcasing the power of advanced data integration in complex biological systems.
original_title: Knowledge Network Embedding of Transcriptomic Data from Spaceflown Mice Uncovers Signs and Symptoms Associated with Terrestrial Diseases

title: NASA GeneLab RNA-seq consensus pipeline: standardized processing of short-read RNA-seq data
abstract: With the development of transcriptomic technologies, we are able to quantify precise changes in gene expression profiles from astronauts and other organisms exposed to spaceflight. Members of NASA GeneLab and GeneLab-associated analysis working groups (AWGs) have developed a consensus pipeline for analyzing short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight-associated experiments. The pipeline includes quality control, read trimming, mapping, and gene quantification steps, culminating in the detection of differentially expressed genes. This data analysis pipeline and the results of its execution using data submitted to GeneLab are now all publicly available through the GeneLab database. We present here the full details and rationale for the construction of this pipeline in order to promote transparency, reproducibility, and reusability of pipeline data; to provide a template for data processing of future spaceflight-relevant datasets; and to encourage cross-analysis of data from other databases with the data available in GeneLab.
summary: NASA GeneLab and its associated working groups developed a consensus pipeline for standardized processing of short-read RNA-sequencing data from spaceflight experiments. This pipeline encompasses quality control, read trimming, mapping, and gene quantification to identify differentially expressed genes. The pipeline and its execution results are now publicly available through the GeneLab database, promoting transparency, reproducibility, and reusability for future spaceflight-relevant datasets and cross-analysis with other databases.
impact: This publication significantly advances space biology by providing a standardized, transparent, and reproducible methodology for analyzing complex transcriptomic data generated from spaceflight. It offers a critical tool for researchers to consistently process RNA-seq data, thereby improving the reliability and comparability of findings related to astronaut health, biological responses to space, and the development of countermeasures. The public availability of the pipeline and data through GeneLab fosters a collaborative scientific environment and serves as a template for future genomics research in space and potentially terrestrial contexts requiring robust data standardization.
original_title: NASA GeneLab RNA-Seq Consensus Pipeline: Standardized Processing of Short-Read RNA-Seq Data

title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice
abstract: Impairment of the central nervous system (CNS) poses a significant health risk for astronauts during long-duration space missions. In this study, we employed an innovative approach by integrating single-cell multiomics (transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) with spatial transcriptomics to elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain in female mice. Our comparative analysis between ground control and spaceflight-exposed animals revealed significant alterations in essential brain processes including neurogenesis, synaptogenesis and synaptic transmission, particularly affecting the cortex, hippocampus, striatum and neuroendocrine structures. Additionally, we observed astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction. At the pathway level, some spaceflight-induced changes in the brain exhibit similarities with neurodegenerative disorders, marked by oxidative stress and protein misfolding. Our integrated spatial multiomics approach serves as a stepping stone towards understanding spaceflight-induced CNS impairments at the level of individual brain regions and cell types, and provides a basis for comparison in future spaceflight studies. For broader scientific impact, all datasets from this study are available through an interactive data portal, as well as the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Open Science Data Repository (OSDR).
summary: This study employed an innovative single-cell and spatial multiomics approach (transcriptomics and chromatin accessibility) to elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain in female mice, specifically addressing CNS impairment risks for astronauts. Comparative analysis revealed significant alterations in key brain processes like neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, and synaptic transmission, particularly in the cortex, hippocampus, striatum, and neuroendocrine structures. Additionally, researchers observed astrocyte activation and signs of immune dysfunction, with some spaceflight-induced brain changes exhibiting similarities to neurodegenerative disorders marked by oxidative stress and protein misfolding.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of spaceflight-induced central nervous system (CNS) impairments by integrating cutting-edge spatial multiomics, providing an unprecedented view at individual brain regions and cell types. The findings, highlighting similarities with neurodegenerative disorders, offer crucial insights for developing countermeasures to protect astronaut health during long-duration space missions. Furthermore, the public availability of all datasets through NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) fosters broader scientific collaboration and serves as a foundational reference for future spaceflight studies, potentially informing terrestrial research into neurodegenerative conditions.

title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos
abstract:
With precious few spaceflight missions, all space-related biological and biomedical-health data are priceless national resources that anyone should be able to easily access. The NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR: https://osdr.nasa.gov/bio) plays a crucial role in ensuring such accessibility, housing comprehensive space-related datasets derived not only from various model organisms but also from non-NASA human astronauts1. These datasets cover a wide spectrum of biological assays conducted at multiple levels, ranging across cells, tissues, organs, and whole organisms. They effectively capture diverse types of data, including ‘omics, phenotypic, physiological, and behavioral changes experienced in space2,3. Additionally, OSDR enriches this data by providing metadata contextualizing each experiment including the associated experimental hardware and environmental telemetry. OSDR has worked with a large and open scientific community to standardize data generation and formatting, enabling advanced analytics, including the use of artificial intelligence (AI) for data analysis.

With the support of NASA’s scientific leadership, the spirit of Open Science has permeated every scientific division at NASA, including the Biological and Physical Science (BPS) Division. The BPS Division has emerged as a pivotal force in fueling humanity’s fascination with space exploration by understanding the mechanisms of life adapting to extreme environmental hazards of deep space4. As NASA launched the ambitious "Transform to Open Science" program (TOPS)5 in 2023, it aims to accelerate the adoption of a more reproducible and transparent approach to research. TOPS also aims to train 20,000 scientists in the art of Open Science by 2028 (https://nasa.github.io/Transform-to-Open-Science/), pushing for better equity and inclusivity in science. Within the BPS Division, the curation of an extensive array of space biological, space health, and mission telemetry data in standardized formats has been vetted by over 500 citizen scientists, members of the NASA OSDR Analysis Working Groups (AWG - https://osdr.nasa.gov/bio/awg/join.html). As a result, OSDR system ensures the invaluable data’s findability, accessibility, interoperability, and reusability (FAIR)6, despite the challenges posed by its multi-hierarchical, multimodal, and heterogeneous nature.

As a celebration of 2023 being the year of Open Science at NASA, a Nature portfolio Collection titled "The Second Space Age: Omics, Platforms, and Medicine Across Orbits7,’’ is a series of inspiring articles enabled by OSDR, enriched by new data generously shared by civilian astronauts aboard the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission. The investigator team involved in this work has embraced Open Science by sharing research data and enabling data mining by the AWG community. Data presented in this Nature portfolio Collection were fully utilized because of the open and accessible nature of the OSDR system. This array of work shows how NASA handled the storage and reuse of a diverse range of data from molecular to ecosystem levels, encompassing tabular, omics, imaging, code, video, biospecimens, and environmental physical-chemical telemetry data. The AWGs played a critical role standardizing metadata and data processing pipelines in OSDR, enabling groundbreaking discoveries in space biology and biomedical health by making meta-analysis possible. In this context, two recent articles involving the AWGs were published in Nature Machine Intelligence and featured in a special issue on AI, detailing the future role of AI and Open Science in deep space biological research8 and biomedical health support9, describing how Open Science and standardization integrated with AI can maximize the value of limited yet vital spaceflight data.

The spirit of Open Science and the invaluable insights from space biology have transcended boundaries, extending their embrace to other vital groups within NASA, including the Human Research Program (HRP) focused on the health and performance of NASA Astronauts. This Open Science approach champions practical, collaborative scientific discovery, with an emphasis on data sharing and immediate applications. Insights from space biology, facilitated by Open Science, are vital not just for aspirational goals like moon and Mars missions, but for direct advancements in human health and technology on earth. This Nature portfolio Collection highlights how collective efforts and open data can drive substantial scientific progress, merging the thrill of cosmic exploration with tangible and immediate benefits.
summary: NASA's Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) is highlighted as a critical national resource that ensures accessible, comprehensive space-related biological and biomedical-health data, adhering to FAIR principles. Supported by initiatives like the "Transform to Open Science" (TOPS) program, which aims to train 20,000 scientists by 2028, and collaboration with over 500 citizen scientists in Analysis Working Groups (AWG), OSDR standardizes diverse datasets to enable advanced analytics, including Artificial Intelligence (AI). This open science approach maximizes the value of limited spaceflight data for scientific discovery, human health, and technological advancements on Earth.
impact: This publication signifies a major advancement in scientific methodology and data infrastructure for space biology and biomedical health, establishing a robust system for reproducible and transparent research through OSDR's adherence to FAIR principles and data standardization. Practically, it enables advanced analytics, AI integration, and meta-analysis of complex spaceflight data, directly supporting future space missions and enhancing astronaut health, with direct benefits for terrestrial human health and technology. The commitment to training 20,000 scientists by 2028 via the TOPS program underscores a broader implication for fostering a more equitable and inclusive scientific community, driving collaborative progress in a critical and data-limited field.
original_title: Biological horizons: pioneering open science in the cosmos

title: Inspiration4 data access through the NASA Open Science Data Repository
abstract: The increasing accessibility of commercial and private space travel necessitates a profound understanding of its impact on human health. The NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) provides transparent and FAIR access to biological studies, notably the SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission, which amassed extensive data from civilian astronauts. This dataset encompasses omics and clinical assays, facilitating comprehensive research on space-induced biological responses. These data allow for multi-modal, longitudinal assessments, bridging the gap between human and model organism studies. Crucially, community-driven data standards established by NASA’s OSDR Analysis Working Groups empower artificial intelligence and machine learning to glean invaluable insights, guiding future mission planning and health risk mitigation. This article presents a concise guide to access and analyze I4 data in OSDR, including programmatic access through GLOpenAPI. This pioneering effort establishes a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs within space agencies, propelling research in the burgeoning field of commercial space travel’s impact on human physiology.
summary: This publication serves as a concise guide to accessing and analyzing the extensive omics and clinical data collected from civilian astronauts during the SpaceX Inspiration4 mission, available through the NASA Open Science Data Repository (OSDR). The objective is to enable comprehensive, multi-modal, and longitudinal research on space-induced biological responses, bridging human and model organism studies. This initiative establishes a precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs within space agencies, advancing research into the physiological impacts of commercial space travel.
impact: This publication holds significant scientific value by democratizing access to extensive omics and clinical data from the Inspiration4 mission through the NASA OSDR, fostering AI/ML-driven insights into space-induced biological responses. Practically, it guides future mission planning, health risk mitigation, and establishes a critical precedent for post-mission health monitoring programs for commercial space travelers. Its broader implications include accelerating research in space physiology and potentially informing terrestrial health challenges by leveraging these comprehensive datasets.

title: NASA GeneLab derived microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens organisms in altered gravitational conditions
abstract: One of the greatest challenges of humanity for deep space exploration is to fully understand how altered gravitational conditions affect human physiology. It is evident that the spaceflight environment causes multiple alterations to musculoskeletal, cardiovascular, immune and central nervous systems, to name a few known effects. To better characterize these biological effects, we compare gene expression datasets from microarray studies found in NASA GeneLab, part of the NASA Open Science Data Repository. In this review, we summarize these archived results for various tissues, emphasizing key genes which are highly reproducible in different mice or human experiments. Such exhaustive mining shows the potential of NASA Open Science data to identify and validate mechanisms taking place when mammalian organisms are exposed to microgravity or other spaceflight conditions. Our comparative meta-analysis findings highlight certain degrees of overlap and reproducibility in genes identified as differentially expressed within musculoskeletal tissues in each species across a variety of altered gravity conditions. However, the level of overlap between species was found to be significantly limited, partly attributed to the limited availability of human samples.
summary: This review compares gene expression datasets from NASA GeneLab microarray studies of Mus musculus and Homo sapiens to characterize how altered gravitational conditions affect mammalian physiology. Key findings indicate reproducible differentially expressed genes within musculoskeletal tissues of each species, but with significantly limited overlap between species, partly due to the scarcity of human samples. This work highlights the potential of NASA Open Science data for identifying and validating biological mechanisms during spaceflight.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of mammalian physiological responses to altered gravity at the molecular level, validating the utility of NASA GeneLab for comprehensive meta-analyses and revealing critical inter-species differences in gene expression. Practically, these insights are crucial for understanding astronaut health risks during deep space exploration and for developing targeted countermeasures against microgravity's effects on multiple physiological systems. Broader implications include informing terrestrial research on conditions like disuse atrophy and emphasizing the need for more extensive human spaceflight data collection and open science data utilization.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Mammalian Gene Expression

title: Celebrating 30 years of access to NASA Space Life Sciences data
abstract: NASA’s space life sciences research programs established a decades-long legacy of enhancing our ability to safely explore the cosmos. From Skylab and the Space Shuttle Program to the NASA Balloon Program and the International Space Station National Lab, these programs generated priceless data that continue to paint a vibrant picture of life in space. These data are available to the scientific community in various data repositories, including the NASA Ames Life Sciences Data Archive (ALSDA) and NASA GeneLab. Here we recognize the 30-year anniversary of data access through ALSDA and the 10-year anniversary of GeneLab.

It highlights how these repositories provide access to "priceless data" from decades of NASA space life sciences research, enhancing our understanding of life in space and our ability to safely explore the cosmos. These efforts underpin open science principles by making valuable data available to the scientific community.
impact: This publication has significant scientific impact by highlighting the crucial role of NASA's ALSDA and GeneLab archives in promoting open science and FAIR data principles for space life sciences research. title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice
abstract:
Aim:
Fluid and macromolecule transport from the interstitium into and through lymphatic vessels is necessary for tissue homeostasis. While lymphatic capillary structure suggests that passive, paracellular transport would be the predominate route of macromolecule entry, active caveolae-mediated transcellular transport has been identified in lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) in vitro. Caveolae also mediate a wide array of endothelial cell processes, including nitric oxide regulation. Thus, how does the lack of caveolae impact “lymphatic function”?
Methods:
Various aspects of lymphatic transport were measured in mice constitutively lacking caveolin-1 (“CavKO”), the protein required for caveolae formation in endothelial cells, and in mice with a LEC-specific Cav1 gene deletion (Lyve1-Cre x Cav1flox/flox; “LyCav”) and ex vivo in their vessels and cells.
Results:
In each model, lymphatic architecture was largely unchanged. The lymphatic conductance, or initial tissue uptake, was significantly higher in both CavKO mice and LyCav mice by quantitative microlymphangiography and the permeability to 70kDa dextran was significantly increased in monolayers of LECs isolated from CavKO mice. Conversely, transport within the lymphatic system to the sentinel node was significantly reduced in anesthetized CavKO and LyCav mice. Isolated, cannulated collecting vessel studies identified significantly reduced phasic contractility when lymphatic endothelium lacks caveolae. Inhibition of nitric oxide synthase was able to partially restore ex vivo vessel contractility.
Conclusion:
Macromolecule transport across lymphatics is increased with loss of caveolae, yet phasic contractility reduced, resulting in reduced overall lymphatic transport function. These studies identify lymphatic caveolar biology as a key regulator of active lymphatic transport functions.
summary: This study aimed to determine how the absence of caveolae affects lymphatic function and fluid/macromolecule transport. Researchers found that while lymphatic architecture was largely unchanged, lymphatic conductance (initial tissue uptake) was significantly higher in CavKO and LyCav mice, and LEC permeability to 70kDa dextran significantly increased. Conversely, transport within the lymphatic system to the sentinel node was significantly reduced, a finding linked to significantly reduced phasic contractility in vessels lacking caveolae, partially restored by nitric oxide synthase inhibition, thereby identifying lymphatic caveolar biology as a key regulator of active lymphatic transport.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of fundamental lymphatic transport mechanisms by elucidating the dichotomous role of caveolae in regulating both permeability and contractile function. While not directly space-focused, understanding the cellular and physiological regulators of fluid and macromolecule transport is highly relevant to astronaut health, particularly regarding fluid shifts, tissue edema, and immune function challenges in microgravity. Broader implications include insights into terrestrial conditions involving lymphatic dysfunction (e.g., lymphedema, inflammation) and guiding future studies on how altered environmental conditions, including spaceflight stressors, might perturb these critical homeostatic processes.
original_title: Dichotomous effects on lymphatic transport with loss of caveolae in mice.

title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on earth and in space
abstract: Human occupied built environments are no longer confined to Earth. In fact, there have been humans living and working in low-Earth orbit on the International Space Station (ISS) since November 2000. With NASA’s Artemis missions and the age of commercial space stations set to begin, more human-occupied spacecraft than ever will be in Earth’s orbit and beyond. On Earth and in the ISS, microbes, especially fungi, can be found in dust and grow when unexpected, elevated moisture conditions occur. However, we do not yet know how indoor microbiomes in Earth-based homes and in the ISS differ due to their unique set of environmental conditions. Here we show that bacterial and fungal communities are different in dust collected from vacuum bags on Earth and the ISS, with Earth-based homes being more diverse (465 fungal OTUs and 237 bacterial ASVs) compared to the ISS (102 fungal OTUs and 102 bacterial ASVs). When dust from these locations were exposed to varying equilibrium relative humidity conditions (ERH), there were also significant fungal community composition changes as ERH and time elevated increased (Bray Curtis: R2 = 0.35, P = 0.001). These findings can inform future spacecraft design to promote healthy indoor microbiomes that support crew health, spacecraft integrity, and planetary protection.
summary: This study investigated bacterial and fungal community differences in indoor dust from Earth-based homes and the International Space Station (ISS), alongside their response to varying moisture conditions. Findings revealed Earth environments were significantly more diverse (465 fungal OTUs, 237 bacterial ASVs) than the ISS (102 fungal OTUs, 102 bacterial ASVs), with fungal communities notably shifting as equilibrium relative humidity increased (Bray Curtis: R2 = 0.35, P = 0.001). These insights are crucial for informing future spacecraft design to support healthy indoor microbiomes, crew health, and spacecraft integrity.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of microbial ecology in built environments by providing a direct comparison of indoor microbiomes between Earth and space habitats. Practically, these findings are critical for future spacecraft design, especially for NASA’s Artemis missions and commercial space stations, to ensure crew health, prevent biodeterioration, and implement planetary protection protocols. The demonstrated fungal community shifts due to humidity (R2 = 0.35, P = 0.001) also hold broader implications for managing microbial growth in other controlled or moisture-prone environments, contributing to a safer and healthier space exploration future.
original_title: Fungal diversity differences in the indoor dust microbiome from built environments on Earth and in space.

title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station
abstract:
Background
The commercialization of space travel will soon lead to many more people living and working in unique built environments similar to the International Space Station, which is a specialized closed environment that contains its own indoor microbiome. Unintended microbial growth can occur in these environments as in buildings on Earth from elevated moisture, such as from a temporary ventilation system failure. This growth can drive negative health outcomes and degrade building materials. We need a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth in these critical indoor spaces.

Results
Here, we demonstrate that even short exposures to varying elevated relative humidity can facilitate rapid microbial growth and microbial community composition changes in dust from spacecraft. We modeled fungal growth in dust from the International Space Station using the time-of-wetness framework with activation and deactivation limited growth occurring at 85% and 100% relative humidity, respectively. Fungal concentrations ranged from an average of 4.4 × 106 spore equivalents per milligram of dust in original dust with no exposure to relative humidity to up to 2.1 × 1010 when exposed to 100% relative humidity for 2 weeks. As relative humidity and time-elevated increased, fungal diversity was significantly reduced for both alpha (Q < 0.05) and beta (R2 = 0.307, P = 0.001) diversity metrics. Bacteria were unable to be modeled using the time-of-wetness framework. However, bacterial communities did change based on constant relative humidity incubations for both beta (R2 = 0.22, P = 0.001) and alpha diversity decreasing with increasing moisture starting at 85% relative humidity (Q < 0.05).

Conclusion
Our results demonstrate that moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft. This predictive model can be expanded upon to include other spacecraft environmental factors such as microgravity, elevated carbon dioxide conditions, and radiation exposure. Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can help better protect astronaut health, fortify spacecraft integrity, and promote planetary protection as human activity increases in low-Earth orbit, the moon, Mars, and beyond.
summary: This study aimed to predict how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station (ISS) to develop models for microbial growth in closed space environments. Researchers demonstrated that even short exposures to elevated relative humidity (RH) facilitate rapid fungal growth and community changes, with fungal concentrations increasing from an average of 4.4 × 10^6 spore equivalents per milligram of dust to up to 2.1 × 10^10 when exposed to 100% RH for two weeks. Fungal diversity was significantly reduced with increased RH (alpha Q < 0.05, beta R^2 = 0.307), indicating that moisture conditions can predict fungal changes to protect astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
impact: This research significantly advances scientific understanding by providing a predictive model for fungal growth in spacecraft dust using a time-of-wetness framework, revealing substantial increases in fungal concentrations (e.g., to 2.1 × 10^10 spore equivalents/mg) under elevated moisture. Practically, these findings are critical for developing proactive countermeasures to safeguard astronaut health, prevent material degradation, and ensure planetary protection as space travel commercializes. Broader implications include extending these predictive models to incorporate other space environmental factors like microgravity and radiation, and potentially informing microbial control strategies in terrestrial built environments.
theme: Space Biology: Microbial Growth in Built Environments
original_title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the International Space Station

title: Aging and Estrogen Status: A Possible Endothelium-Dependent Vascular Coupling Mechanism in Bone Remodeling
abstract: Bone loss with aging and menopause may be linked to vascular endothelial dysfunction. The purpose of the study was to determine whether putative modifications in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur are associated with changes in trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) with altered estrogen status in young (6 mon) and old (24 mon) female Fischer-344 rats. Animals were divided into 6 groups: 1) young intact, 2) old intact, 3) young ovariectomized (OVX), 4) old OVX, 5) young OVX plus estrogen replacement (OVX+E2), and 6) old OVX+E2. PNA endothelium-dependent vasodilation was assessed in vitro using acetylcholine. Trabecular bone volume of the distal femoral metaphysis was determined by microCT. In young rats, vasodilation was diminished by OVX and restored with estrogen replacement (intact, 82±7; OVX, 61±9; OVX+E2, 90±4%), which corresponded with similar modifications in BV/TV (intact, 28.7±1.6; OVX, 16.3±0.9; OVX+E2, 25.7±1.4%). In old animals, vasodilation was unaffected by OVX but enhanced with estrogen replacement (intact, 55±8; OVX, 59±7; OVX+E2, 92±4%). Likewise, modifications in BV/TV followed the same pattern (intact, 33.1±1.6; OVX, 34.4±3.7; OVX+E2, 42.4±2.1%). Furthermore, in old animals with low endogenous estrogen (i.e., intact and old OVX), vasodilation was correlated with BV/TV (R2 = 0.630; P<0.001). These data demonstrate parallel effects of estrogen on vascular endothelial function and BV/TV, and provide for a possible coupling mechanism linking endothelium-dependent vasodilation to bone remodeling.
summary: This study investigated whether changes in endothelium-dependent vasodilation of the femur's principal nutrient artery are linked to alterations in trabecular bone volume (BV/TV) due to altered estrogen status in young (6 mon) and old (24 mon) female rats. In young rats, ovariectomy (OVX) diminished vasodilation (from 82±7% to 61±9%) and BV/TV (from 28.7±1.6% to 16.3±0.9%), effects reversed by estrogen replacement. In old animals with low endogenous estrogen, vasodilation correlated with BV/TV (R2 = 0.630; P<0.001), demonstrating parallel effects of estrogen and suggesting a possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
impact: This research significantly advances understanding of the complex interplay between estrogen, vascular endothelial function, and bone health, particularly highlighting a potential endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism. For space missions, these findings are crucial for developing countermeasures to mitigate bone loss and maintain cardiovascular health in astronauts, especially female astronauts, who may experience altered estrogen status or aging effects. Broadly, this work has implications for terrestrial applications in addressing osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease in aging and postmenopausal women, informing integrated therapeutic approaches and future research directions.
original_title: Aging and estrogen status: A possible endothelium-dependent vascular coupling mechanism in bone remodeling.
